ul.li: A theorem is a statement can be shown to be true. (an important statement)
A proposition is a "less important" theorem.
The tools we use to prove a theorem are axioms (or postulates) which are basic assumptions we make, as well as other theorems we've already proven.
A less important theorem that will be helpful in proving others is called a lemma.
A corollary is a theorem that follows directly from a theorem just proved.
A conjecture is a statement that we think my be true (our intuition suggests it)

statement.p: "If n is an odd integer, then n^2 is odd."
This means for the universe of discourse of all integers: \forall n ((n is odd ) \to (n^2 is odd)))

note.statement: The universe of discourse was implied in the general statement above. Mathematical propositions will almost always omit the words "for all."

subsection.title: Direct Proof
subsection.p: A direct proof is used when proving a proposition of the form p \to q. The goal is to show q is true when we assume p is true. Here's the model:

example.statement: Prove that the sum of two odd numbers is even.
Prove that if n is even, then n^2 is even.
Prove that if m+n and n + p are even integers, then m+p is even.

introduction.p: We still want to show p \to q is true, but perhaps that's difficult to approach directly. There are several different indirect proofs. The most frequent are approaches are proofs by contraposition and proofs by contradication.

subsubsection.title: Proof by Contraposition
subsubsection.p: . A proof by contraposition is a direct proof of \neg q \to \neg p. Here's the model:

proof.p: Show \neg p is true. Therefore, p \to q is true by contraposition.

subsubsection.p: Remember that \neg q \to \neg p \equiv p \to q, so this is a valid argument.

example.statement: Show that if n is an integer and n^3 + 5 is odd, then n is even.
Prove that if n^2 is even, then n is even.

subsubsection.title: Proof by Contradiction
subsubsection.p: A proof by contradiction relies on the fact that \neg (p \wedge \neg q) \equiv (p \to q). We'll assume both that p is true, and we assume the opposite or q is true. Here's the model:

proof.p: Assume p is true, and further assume that \neg q is true
Arrive at a logical contradiction. Some impossibility. Therefore, p \to q is true by contradiction.

subsection.title: Proofs of equivalence
subsection.p: For statements which are "if an only if:" p \iff q we need to prove both p \to q and its converse q \to p.

example.statement: Prove that n is even if and only if n^2 is even.

solution.p: We actually did this in the two previous subsections. The forward direction and the converse.

example.statement: Prove that n is even if and only if 7n+4 is even.

Prove the following are equivalent:
a\lt b
The average of a and b is greater than a
The average of a and b is less than b

subsection.title: Proof by cases
subsection.p:
What if the cases might be the same? Below, we have two cases, either x is odd and y is even, or x is even and y is odd:
Prove that 5x + 5y is an odd integer when x and y are integers of opposite parity (not both even, not both odd).

subsection.title: Existence Proofs
subsection.p: The claim of an existence theorem is that there is some object that has a property. A constructive proof is one which, during the argumentation, tells the reader specifically how to come up with the object in question. A nonconstructive proof merely confirms the existence of an object, but doesn't give any detail as to how to find it.

example.statement: Prove that either 2 \cdot 10^{500} + 15 or 2 \cdot 10^{500} + 16 is not a perfect square.
Show that between any two rational numbers is another rational number.

subsection.title: Uniqueness proofs
subsection.p:
The claim of a uniqueness theorem is that there exists an element that has a desired property, and that no other element has this property. The outline of our proof is often:
Prove the existence of x, some element that has the property we want.
Assume that a second element, y also has that property.
Conclude that x = y

example.statement: Show that if a, b, c are real numbers, then thare is a unique solution to the algebraic equation ax+b=c.
Show that if n is an odd integer, then there exists a unique integer k such that n = (k-2) + (k+3)

definition.p:
A vacuous statement is one that is true because the hypothesis is false. You can prove a statement is true immediately.
If I play in the Super Bowl, I will throw the game winning touchdown.
Vacuous statements are kind of annoying... since I won't ever play in the Super Bowl, it doesn't matter what the truth value of the touchdown statement is. F\to T \equiv T and F \to F \equiv T just the same.

If we know that the conclusion of a statement is true, then the statement has a trivial proof.
Let P(x) be the statement If x\in \mathbb{R} and x \gt 0 , then x^2 + 1 \ge 0.
Since we know that x^2 \ge 0 for any real number, x^2 + 1 \ge x^2 \ge 0. We didn't need the hypothesis x \gt 0. This is a trivial proof.

subsection.title: Counterexamples Revisited
subsection.p: Recall in math propositions, the universal quantifier is implied and is usually omitted.

example.statement:
Each of the following statements is false. Find a specific counterexample and explain why.
If n is a real number, then (n+4)^2 = n^2 + 16.
Every integer is the sum of the squares of two integers.
\forall x \forall y (x^2 = y^2 \to x = y) where the domain of all variables is the set of all integers.
The product of two irrational numbers is irrational.
The sum of two irrational numbers is irrational.
